title: Houses
summary: Vocabulary for talking about houses, including rooms and parts of a house, adjectives for describing houses, and verbs related to repair and renovation.

sections.heading: Rooms and Parts of a House
sections.content: This section covers common names for different rooms and areas in and around a house.

examples.definition: A room at the top of a house under the roof.
examples.example: I store old clothes and books in the attic.

examples.definition: An open space under the roof of a house, often used as a bedroom or living area.
examples.example: She turned the loft into a cozy reading area.

examples.definition: The floor of a house or building which is partly or entirely below ground level.
examples.example: There’s a ping pong table and a home cinema projector in our basement.

examples.definition: A room below ground level in a house used for storage, especially wine or food.
examples.example: Grandpa keeps his wine collection in the cellar.

examples.definition: The floor area at the top of a staircase.
examples.example: There’s a small table on the landing with a vase of flowers.

examples.definition: A small building used for storage or hobbies, often in a garden.
examples.example: Dad keeps his gardening tools in the shed.

examples.definition: A covered area next to the entrance of a house.
examples.example: We enjoy sitting on the porch during summer evenings.

examples.definition: An outdoor area next to a house used for eating or relaxing.
examples.example: They have a barbecue grill on their patio.

examples.definition: A room where children can play.
examples.example: The kids are playing in the playroom.

examples.definition: A room in a house used for work or study.
examples.example: He’s reading in the study.

examples.definition: A small room or closet in a house where food is stored.
examples.example: We keep our canned goods in the pantry.

examples.definition: A room in a house where you keep things such as a washing machine, sink, and cleaning equipment.
examples.example: We put the dirty laundry in the utility room.

sections.heading: Describing a House
sections.content: This section covers adjectives and expressions used to describe houses and rooms.

examples.definition: Large in size or area, allowing you to move freely and relax.
examples.example: Our new living room is so spacious that we can have a big sofa and a coffee table in it.

examples.definition: Very small and without enough space for moving around comfortably.
examples.example: The old kitchen was cramped; it was too small for a table.

examples.definition: Small, warm, and comfortable, making you feel relaxed.
examples.example: The small country house was cozy, with a warm fireplace and soft lighting.

examples.definition: Having a lot of natural light from the sun, making it bright.
examples.example: My bedroom is light and sunny, perfect for reading during the day.

examples.definition: Not having much light, so it looks shadowy or gloomy.
examples.example: The basement is dark, and we need to use extra lights when we go down there.

examples.definition: A furnished house or room has furniture in it; unfurnished means it does not.
examples.example: The apartment came furnished, so it already had beds, tables, a sofa, etc.

examples.definition: A house with two levels or floors.
examples.example: We live in a two-story house, with bedrooms upstairs and a living room downstairs.

examples.phrase: In good condition / In bad condition
examples.definition: Well maintained and without damage (good) or not maintained and needing repair (bad).
examples.example: Our home is in good condition because we recently painted it and fixed the roof.

examples.definition: In a place that is convenient or desirable, often close to shops or schools.
examples.example: Our house is in a good location, close to the school and the grocery store.

sections.heading: Verbs Related to Repair and Renovation
sections.content: This section covers common verbs used for fixing, improving, and maintaining houses.

examples.definition: To work on something that is broken so it is no longer broken.
examples.example: I need to fix the broken chair in the dining room.

examples.definition: To make a room or house more attractive by adding things like paint, wallpaper, or ornaments.
examples.example: We will decorate our living room with new curtains and a rug.

examples.definition: To make big improvements by repairing and decorating a house or room.
examples.example: We are going to renovate the old house to make it look new.

examples.definition: To place something like equipment or furniture into a house or room so it can be used.
examples.example: They will put in a new sink in the kitchen next week.

examples.definition: To add materials to walls, roofs, or floors to improve heat or noise conditions.
examples.example: We should insulate the attic to keep the house warmer in winter.

examples.definition: To do home improvement or repair work by yourself without hiring professionals.
examples.example: On the weekend, I’m going to do some DIY and build a bookshelf.

examples.definition: To do routine work to keep your house clean and organized.
examples.example: Every Saturday, I do housework like cleaning the floors and dusting.
